value.name: KVN (Korean VLBI Network) - KASI
value.snippet: The Korean VLBI Network (KVN) is a very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) network in Korea operating at millimeter wavelengths.

value.name: Korean VLBI Network - Wikipedia
value.snippet: The Korean VLBI Network ( KVN) is a radio astronomy observatory located in South Korea. It comprises three 21-meter radio telescopes that function as an interferometer, using the technique of very-long-baseline interferometry (VLBI). Contents 1 Characteristics 2 Key science 3 Visiting 4 See also 5 References 6 External links Characteristics [ edit]

value.name: Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute
value.snippet: The Korean VLBI Network (KVN) is a very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) network in Korea operating at millimeter wavelengths. It consists of three 21-m radio telescopes located in Seoul, in Ulsan, and on the Jeju Island, Korea: KVN Yonsei Radio Observatory (KY), KVN Ulsan Radio Observatory (KU), and KVN Tamna Radio Observatory (KT). More

value.name: Korean VLBI Network (KVN) - Taeduk Radio Astronomy Observatory
value.snippet: Since the KVN antennas are operated remotely from the AOC, it is necessary for the AOC operator to know the weather conditions which could influence the VLBI data quality during observations. There is a weather station at each KVN observatory sending information on the air temperature, dew point, wind speed, wind direction and air pressure to the AOC.

value.name: Millimeter-wave Receiver Optics for Korean VLBI Network
value.snippet: The Korean VLBI (Very Long Baseline Interferometer) Network project (KVN) is constructing three stations around Korea equipped with 21-meter diameter shaped Cassegrain antennas. The project started in 2001 and will provide astronomy and earth science communities with an observation facility of high spatial resolution.
